title: How to Get an Idea for a Story

steps.headline: Look around your home.
steps.description: Do you see anything with a story behind it? Like that necklace grandma gave you, or the blue ribbon for the soccer tournament? Put that story down on paper.

steps.headline: Look around your outside.
steps.description: For example, if you live in a nature filled place, take a look at the leaves and how they sway in the wind and those small, delicate butterflies that flutter from flower to flower. Writing down notes of what you see, touch, taste, hear and smell will help you on the road to coming up with a new story idea.

steps.headline: Watch random people walk down the street and write a pretend life story for them.
steps.description: It may seem strange, but you never know where doing this might lead by way of a character leading a curious life. If there aren't people around, try Googling up pictures of random people and using them instead. Try people watching when at your favorite coffee shop or while waiting for a bus. These don't have to be stories that take forever to write, either. You can just quickly jot down ideas or doodle things that interest you or that you think would make for a good story.

parts.name: Getting Inspired by the Online World

steps.headline: Look online for a list or writing topics.
steps.description: You can find plenty of topics that you would have never thought of by searching websites, search engines and article sites. Look for listicles which list many different things for each topic of interest to you.

steps.headline: Browse the internet for news items.
steps.description: The news can inspire many ideas, especially if the news items provoke feelings of joy, anger, annoyance, compassion, and so on. Bookmark or keep copies of news items that you like, for future reference.

steps.headline: Watch your favorite video clips, movies or other video material online.
steps.description: Go to your country's archives to find films about the past as a great source of historic inspiration.

steps.headline: Think about movies and books you've enjoyed and what made you enjoy them.
steps.description: Was it a certain type of character or a setting? Try incorporating similar elements into your own story.

steps.headline: Write about your favorite book or movie.
steps.description: Just be sure you don't plagiarize, if you plan on showing your story to others.

parts.name: Getting inspired by your own life

steps.headline: Think of an event that has happened in your life recently, or maybe something that happened a long time ago.
steps.description:
How did it affect you? Did it have a lasting impression, or even impact? Jot down your thoughts and try crafting a story from that. steps.headline: Write about the dream you had last night.
steps.description:
The plotlines for numerous famous stories and novels were hatched in the dreams of their author's. It may seem unlikely, but your dream could become a bestseller someday! Keeping a journal and pen on your night stand right before you go to sleep is helpful. steps.headline: Try random words or phrases.
steps.description: For example: a secret diary, a squishy banana and a sneaky babysitter. Take your three phrases or words and try to make a story out of it. You'll never know how it will turn out if you don't try!

steps.headline: Choose a genre to be inspired by.
steps.description: The type of story you choose to write about must be developed around a certain genre and is the most important part of coming up with a story. Whether it's a romance, teen fiction or a thriller, selecting the genre may be a good source of inspiration for more ideas.
